awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF: A Global Survey of Atmospheric Hydroperoxides: HOx Cycling, Tropospheric Ozone and Chemistry-Climate Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellow to investigate the atmospheric chemistry of biogenic isoprene emissions.  Isoprene can be produced by terrestrial ecosystems and can react differently in the atmosphere depending on what other gases and aerosols are present.  Nitrogen oxide concentrations can influence the extent to which isoprene contributes to the formation of ozone or very small organic particles in the atmosphere.

This research investigates isoprene oxidation processes in conditions with low concentrations of nitrogen oxides (NOx), and the effects of isoprene oxidation products on ozone and the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA).  The focus is on the formation, destruction and physical uptake processes of hydroperoxides. The research is expected to address long-standing questions about hydrogen peroxide deposition rates and its impact on the budget of hydrogen oxide radicals (HOx), and lead to new parameterizations based on in-situ data.  The contribution of isoprene to SOA formation will be investigated by examining the sources and sinks of each oxidation reaction across a wide variety of environmental conditions.  A novel instrument will be deployed for the separation of isoprene oxidation products to examine the different chemical fates of each.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to provide measurements of hydroperoxides throughout the global remote atmosphere. These measurements provide insights into the chemistry and dynamics that impact the distribution of atmospheric oxidants, such as HOx and ozone. Atmospheric oxidants control the lifetime of greenhouse gases, aerosol formation, and pollution transport. Therefore, understanding what controls their distribution in the atmosphere is important to predicting these phenomena in the future. These measurements were successfully obtained as part of the Atmospheric Tomography campaign (ATom), an airborne sampling mission that took place over four seasonal deployments from 2016-2018. This data set represents a comprehensive, statistical sampling of the remote troposphere.

Ongoing analysis will address large gaps in the global budgets of small oxygenated volatile organic compounds. Understanding the sources and sinks of small oxygenates is important to provide a complete understanding of the self-cleansing capacity of the atmosphere. Another important outcome of this work will assess the ocean's ability to uptake peroxides and other reactive trace gases by directly measuring their fluxes into or out of the ocean. These measurements taken over the open ocean over a wide range of conditions may help improve our understanding of oceanic uptake of radical reservoirs and oxidation chemistry in the remote marine boundary layer.
